title: 105_hr2985
content: Aliens are ineligible for visas and excluded from admission for nonpayment of child support. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for visas and entry if they fail to pay child support exceeding $5,000 as per the Immigration and Nationality Act. This amendment applies to visas issued 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make aliens deportable for nonpayment of child support exceeding $5,000. Additionally, aliens can be ineligible for naturalization if they fail to pay child support. Aliens may be ineligible for naturalization if they fail to pay child support as legally obligated. The amendment applies to naturalization applications filed 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, certain arriving aliens can be served legal process in child support cases. Immigration officers can serve legal process on alien applicants for admission to enforce child support obligations, as defined by the Social Security Act. This authority is subject to state law and includes serving writs, orders, or summonses issued by courts or administrative agencies. Alien applicants for admission can be served legal process by immigration officers to enforce child support obligations, as defined by the Social Security Act. The amendment made by this section applies to aliens applying for admission to the United States 180 days after the enactment of this Act. The amendment allows the Immigration and Naturalization Service to request information from the Secretary regarding delinquent child support payments by aliens.
